title: Boris says ‘we’ve got a deal’ despite DUP saying they can’t stand by it
text:
Boris Johnson emerged out of the back door of Downing Street before announcing a deal had been struck (Picture: Getty)

Britain and the EU have reached a new Brexit deal, Boris Johnson has announced.

The Prime Minister said he had a ‘great new deal’ that would allow the UK to ‘take back control.’

The House of Commons is now set to vote on Saturday although the PM could struggle to get the deal through a bitterly divided House of Commons.

As he left for Brussels, Mr Johnson tweeted: ‘We’ve got a great new deal that takes back control — now Parliament should get Brexit done on Saturday so we can move on to other priorities like the cost of living, the NHS, violent crime and our environment.’

Northern Ireland’s DUP immediately said they would not support the new deal.

The party wields influence over Tory Brexiteers and their votes would be vital for Mr Johnson’s minority Tory government.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Labour called it a ‘sell-out deal’ adding it was worse than the one Theresa May negotiated, which Westminster rejected three times.

The Lib Dems said they were more determined than ever to stop Brexit and vowed to press on with proposals for a second referendum.

To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

European commission President Jean-Claude Juncker says there is a deal (Picture: AFP)

The legal text on a new deal was agreed between negotiators at the EU summit in Brussels.

Mr Johnson is on his way to Belgium where all 27 EU member states will vote on the divorce package later today.

It is expected to pass after European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said: ‘Where there is a will, there is a #deal – we have one!

‘It’s a fair and balanced agreement for the EU and the UK and it is testament to our commitment to find solutions.’

Leader of the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) Arlene Foster has said they will not support the deal (Picture: LNP)

Sterling surged more than 1%, reaching a five-month high against the US dollar.

British share prices also rallied after the announcement that an agreement had been reached.

This is breaking and will be updated.
